covered: GET Valid Request: Numerous scenarios verify successful retrieval (default params, offset/limit, combinations of booleans, audit levels).
Empty Response: Scenarios for no accounts and offset beyond data (TC08, TC09) validate empty-array responses.
Pagination behavior: Many cases cover offset/limit semantics, boundaries, default limit, large-volume requests, and regression boundary (TC02, TC19, TC21, TC27, TC28, TC46).
Query Parameters validation: Valid and invalid values for offset, limit, boolean and enum (audit) are covered (TC10–TC13, TC38, TC39).
Boolean parameter interactions: Tests cover both single and combined boolean parameters and malformed boolean handling (TC03, TC04, TC26, TC42, TC38).
Audit levels: FULL, MINIMAL, NONE and presence/absence behavior are tested (TC01, TC05, TC06, TC45, TC33).
Authorization: Unauthorized and invalid-token scenarios are present (TC15, TC16).
Error handling: Many HTTP error conditions are covered (400 for bad params, 401, 403 not explicitly but 401 present, 405 method not allowed TC40, 503 service unavailable TC17).
Security: SQL injection and XSS attempts are tested (TC23, TC24).
Integration / dependency failures and recovery: Dependency unavailable and recovery scenarios for balance and audit services are tested (TC32, TC37).
Performance & Concurrency: Large data performance and concurrent requests tested (TC19, TC20).
Edge cases & state variations: Numerous edge/state cases (partial inputs, small dataset, max/min values, extra params ignored) are included (TC25, TC30, TC31, TC34–TC36, TC41, TC47–TC50).
Accessibility: Response structure / descriptive errors considered (TC34, TC35).
gaps: Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests validate rate limiting, request throttling, or behavior when limit exceeded by frequency.
Caching Behavior / Headers: No scenarios check caching-related response headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GET behavior.
403 Forbidden: Authorization tests cover 401 but do not assert 403 behavior for authenticated-but-forbidden users or role-based access control.
Content-Type & Schema Validation: No explicit tests asserting Content-Type (application/json) or strict schema/field types beyond presence/absence; no contract/schema conformance tests.
Server Errors (500/502/504): General server-side failure modes other than 503 (e.g., 500 internal errors, dependency 502/504) are not covered.

Rate/Load spike / graceful degradation: While heavy load and performance are included, there is no test for graceful degradation or circuit-breaker behavior under extreme load beyond response-time bounds.
Cache invalidation / staleness: No tests ensure data freshness when balances or audit info change between calls (stale-cached responses).
403 vs 401 differentiation and role-based cases: No scenarios for valid auth but insufficient privileges or scope-limited tokens.

Schema-level negative tests for Account object fields: Missing tests for malformed/missing required account fields in responses (ensuring response objects match API contract with required keys and types).
recommendations: Add rate-limiting and throttling tests: simulate burst requests and ensure correct status (429) or documented server behavior.
Add caching/conditional GET tests: verify ETag/Cache-Control/Last-Modified headers, and behavior for If-None-Match and If-Modified-Since requests.
Add 403 / role-based access tests: include cases for authenticated users lacking privileges to confirm 403 handling.

Add schema/contract tests: validate Content-Type header and that each Account object strictly conforms to the API schema (required fields, field types), including negative tests when dependent services return malformed data.
Add server-error simulations: include 500/502/504 scenarios (e.g., DB failure, downstream timeouts) to ensure meaningful error responses and safe failure modes.
Add cache-staleness and invalidation tests: verify that changes to account balance/audit are reflected appropriately and caches are invalidated or updated per headers.
Add tests for rate/behavior under extreme load and circuit-breaker behavior: ensure graceful degradation and documented limits are enforced.
